physDesc.p: This letter is one pagelong. It is typed on stationerythat says “Sevenels Brookline.” On the leftupper corner is penciled in two diagonal lines (right bottom going up to the left) “Jan 20 1915 Ans. longhand H.[cut word]

div.p: Your letter was a truly disconcerting one; I do not know what to do about it. It is not so much the presence of Ezra in March which would make it inadvisable for you to put any of my poems in that number, but the fact that I understood you to say that Fletcher’s article on me was going in in March; and I do not think any of my poems had better appear in the same number with that article.

Now as to April – of course, it is a little bit late, for Greenslet told me yesterday that he expected to get the book out toward the end of March. But books often get delayed and if you choose to risk publishing the poems in April, I do not think there would be any objection.

May I point out to you that some of these poems you have had a year, and it is a little hard to have one’s poems hung up for a year, as you know. I think it would be better to have my group in in May or June, as you planned, rather than have it come out simultaneously with the Anthology. If you want to print the two poems that you have which are included in the Anthology in April, well and good; I should be delighted. If, on the other hand, you wish to send them back to me and have me substitute two others for them, I can do that too, although naturally that would not be so satisfactory to me.

Of course, I should like best to have you print them in April, and have me substitute two others to make the group as long as it was before for, say, June. If you will let me know exactly what you would like to do as soon as possible, I should be very glad. I cannot change the poems in the Anthology, as I told you, on account of their being passed upon by the others, and the book goes to press immediately.

I do not believe there is the slightest objection to Hilda’s things going in with Ezra’s, or you could put her in April. I understood Richard to tell me in London that you had accepted her flower poems, but there seems to be some mistake about that; and certainly “The Pool” appearing in April, even if the book came out a week or so before, would not matter with her any more than it would with me. Anyway, please let me know as soon as possible, so that I can send you substitute poems.
